6.0   EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

It is the policy of the Adient to place the highest priority on employee safety and health and on protection of the community from all plant-induced environmental conditions. Experience has shown that proper planning and an organized approach will reduce the effects of emergency events.  Prompt internal and external communications, emergency equipment, and trained personnel are the key ingredients of this plan.  Adient's policy provides for external communications with local and county-wide response agencies.  The Highland County HAZMAT Team has the lead responsibility in responding to major releases of TDI that would have the potential to affect off-site locations.

 
7.0   PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Adient, under the recent RMP program, and earlier Superfund Amendments and Reauthorization Act (SARA) Title III Community Right-to-Know Act compliance programs, has organized its management system to effectively address hazards and potential risks. The RMP regulation defines a worst-case release of a liquid as an instantaneous spill of a single vessel accounting for passive mitigation including physical barriers that prevent the spread of the resulting pool and enclosures which would limit the rate of evaporation.  The temperature of the release is the maximum daily temperature over the past three years or the process temperature, whichever is higher.  The release to the atmosphere is assumed to be at ground level and dispersion conditions are set to atmospheric stability category F (very stable) and a surface (10 m) wind speed of 1.5 m/sec.
   
In accordance with revised Risk Management Plan requirements promulgated on April 9, 2004 and in deference to the concerns of the Department of Homeland Security, this executive summary does not include a description of the release scenarios and their consequences.  Specific information regarding the off-site hazards assessment for worst-case and alternative releases is included in the RMP data elements.

3.0 OFF-SITE HAZARDS ASSESSMENT

For the purposes of developing and maintaining adequate RMPlans, the U.S. EPA has defined in its governing rules and guidance a series of modeling methods and assumptions which are to be utilized as administrative guides for planning purposes.  In order to standardize and simplify to a practical level the many factors that can potentially occur in an accidental release situation, some of these assumptions may not take into account the available preventive measures or mitigation methods that would diminish or even eliminate the implied risks that are suggested by worst-case analyses.  For that reason, both the results for the standardized worst-case defined by the U.S. EPA methods and an alternative case, which is considered by Adient to more realistically represent situations that may possibly, but rarely, occur within the lifetime of the facility, are presented and described.
 
To ensure that mitigation measures and emergency response plans are appropriate, potential release scenarios are considered.  The Adient Greenfield facility works closely with the local LEPC and Fire Department. The railcar and the tank truck share the unloading platform which is used to fill up to six storage tanks (1 - 5000, 3 - 4295 and 2 - 3431) for a capacity of 24,747 gallons located inside of the plant, within a specially designed containment room.  The threshold quantity for the Risk Management Plan for TDI is 10,000 lb. With a density of 10.2 lb per gallon the maximum amount of TDI that can be stored at the plant is 254,867 lbs, which includes 4 - 60 gallons day tanks.
 
When the truck/railcar arrives it is inspected for any visible signs of damage or leaks.  Appropriate precautions and procedures are implemented if a truck/railcar is found to be deficient.  The railcar/truck is depressurized prior to connecting the offloading system.  Once the railcar/truck is depressurized the offloading system is connected and then the railcar/truck and storage tanks are slightly pressurized with a dry air blanket to prevent moisture buildup in the system.  The entire contents of the railcar/truck is transferred into six indoor storage tanks using blanket pressure; or our alternative pump system.  Due to the continuous operation of foam production, when TDI is required to be transferred to wet system day tank the pump in the storage tank room is activated.  The transfer operation ceases when the day tank sensor indicates that it is full or if filling has not been completed in a specified time (which could indicate a fill problem or leak).

The 60-gallon day tanks for each line are located on mezzanines.  Each day tank has a dry air blanket to prevent moisture.  TDI is transferred to the pour head through the wet system, consisting of a conditioning pump, filter and heat exchanger followed by a metering pump (4000 psi) and which sends high pressure TDI through stainless steel piping to the pour heads. Adient has developed a management system to implement and maintain compliance with the Accidental Release Prevention (ARP) programs.  This management system identifies lines of responsibility for the entire program and each of its key elements.
Figure 1-1 identifies the key positions within the corporate structure that will provide this support. 

 
2.0   PROCESS AND SUBSTANCE SUBJECT TO 40 CFR PART 68

Adient in Greenfield Ohio operates a process to manufacture polyurethane foam that uses LUPRANATE®8020 ISOCYANATE, a liquid chemical that contains a toxic substance regulated under EPA's Risk Management Program (40 CFR Part 68), toluene diisocyanate (unspecified isomers, CAS 26471-62-5) referred to here as TDI and is subject to U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (U.S. EPA) regulations governing Accidental Release Prevention (ARP) Requirements: Risk Management Programs under Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act (40 CFR Part 68), because TDI is present in amounts exceeding the 10,000 lb regulated quantity.

TDI is liquid with a sharp, pungent odor and toxic from acute (short-term) exposures.  The odor threshold for TDI is 0.17 parts per million (ppm).  Acute exposure to high levels of TDI in humans, via inhalation, results in severe irritation of the skin and eyes and affects the respiratory, gastrointestinal, and central nervous systems (CNS).  The toxic endpoint for acute exposures established by EPA for Risk Management Programs is 7 mg/m3 (1 ppmv).
